categories.name: Syntax & Compilation
categories.description: Code compiles without errors, proper syntax and language conventions, appropriate use of language features relevant to Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Logic & Correctness
categories.description: Algorithm correctness, proper implementation of requirements, handles edge cases appropriately, demonstrates understanding of Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Output & Functionality
categories.description: Produces expected output format, meets all functional requirements, handles input/output correctly, demonstrates working solution.

categories.name: Style & Documentation
categories.description: Clear variable and function names, proper indentation and formatting, appropriate comments, follows coding best practices.

category_scores.reasoning: The code is syntactically correct and follows Java conventions. It compiles without errors and uses appropriate language features. The class and method definitions are well-structured.

The constructor for the default cuboid correctly initializes the values. However, the `getVolume()` method has a logical error; it incorrectly calculates the volume as `l * h` instead of `l * w * h`. All other methods and constructor logic are correct.

The `displayInfo` method is implemented and attempts to display the required information. However, due to the incorrect `getVolume()` calculation, the volume output is wrong for both objects. The output format otherwise matches the requirements. The test program correctly instantiates and displays information for both cuboids.
Variable and method names are clear and follow Java conventions. Indentation and formatting are consistent. No comments or documentation were provided, which is a slight drawback.

feedback.overall_comment: The submission demonstrates a good understanding of object-oriented programming principles in Java, including class/object creation, constructors, and methods. The code is well-organized and mostly correct. The primary issue is a logical error in the `getVolume()` method, which needs to be fixed. Additionally, incorporating comments would enhance the documentation and maintainability of the code.
strengths: Proper implementation of constructors, including the use of `this` to call another constructor.
Correct implementation of getter methods and `getSurfaceArea()` method.
Clear and consistent naming conventions for variables and methods.
Well-structured class definition and appropriate use of access modifiers (private for attributes).
The test program (`main` method) correctly instantiates and utilizes the `Cuboid` objects.
areas_for_improvement: The `getVolume()` method needs to be corrected to accurately calculate the volume of the cuboid (l * w * h).
Add comments to explain the purpose of the class, its attributes, and methods to improve code documentation.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Volume Formula
misconceptions.description: The student seems to have confused the formula for the volume of a cuboid, omitting the width (`w`) in the calculation.

evidence.note: The getVolume method currently calculates volume as l * h, omitting w.
